meeting_annotations.transcript: So do we um two things, one would be the introductions as you've been doing just a brief statement of who you are and where you are, but I think most importantly a few sentences about what you do and as I said to my group last time that includes sort of the tools that you have in your toolbox, what kind of perspectives you bring to the table as others are looking for those to partner with on proposals that would be helpful.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Maggie Osburn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, I'm Maggie Osburn. I'm uh almost associate professor at Northwestern and um I'm an isotope organic geobiologist, so I study microbes living in weirdo places doing weirdo things. Um, and I use the tools of organic geochemistry and isotopes and sometimes molecular biology and cultivation to better understand what those things are doing. And in terms of extremes of places given that we're talking about extremophiles, um, I I have played around um in hot springs, that's where I started. Um, I'm currently working in some ultra hypersaline environments and I spent about the last eight years thinking about the deep subsurface and shallow subsurface.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: And I have um going to the right, I have Aaron next.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Aaron Engelhart - U of MN
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hey guys, um am I unmuted and everything? I'm just checking this. All right, great. Uh yeah, Aaron Engelhart. I'm an assistant professor at the University of Minnesota. Uh my lab works on uh prebiotic chemistry uh at the point where you kind of start to get assemblies. So moving past uh sort of simple small molecules but before early cells. So things like uh you know the RNA world, how primitive cells formed from simple precursors like fatty acids. Um, with regard to the prompt and why I put this as one of the ones that I was particularly interested in the last three years or so, uh we started doing a lot of work on uh RNA world type scenarios in hypersaline environments and in particular Mars.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Uh Jeff next.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Jeffrey Marlow (Boston University)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, hello. Uh assistant professor of biology, Boston University. Uh and mostly interested in um really looking at the metabolic activity of complex microbial communities specifically regarding their precise spatial arrangements in situ, um micro micro micro mineral interactions. Um and kind of mapping things out from the micro scale to a uh sort of regional scale ideally. Uh field sites, this usually happens in the deep sea, methane seeps and manganese nodules.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. And this person I know a little bit, Stephanie.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephanie Olson (Purdue University)
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's an understatement. Hi, I'm I'm Stephanie Olson and um I'm an assistant professor in Earth atmospheric and planetary science at Purdue. Um, I study the coevolution of life and environment here on earth, particularly in the very distant past and I think a lot about how this informs planetary habitability um and exoplanet biosignatures. Um, my primary tools are 3D models for marine biogeochemistry um and global climate models as well.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Thank you. And last but certainly not least, Amanda.
